div.head: Excerpta comment
div.p: ´ ] The biblical text seems to be the source for at least some terms of the excerpt concerning the names used to define pagan cult objects. In the usual list, some quite unfavorable words appear. Indeed, the pair προσοχθίσματα (‘offences’) and βδελύγματα (‘abominations’) recalls LXX De. 7, 25‒6, and, shortly after, ἔργα χειρῶν (‘works of hands’) undoubtedly echoes LXX Ps. 113; in both of these passages, pagan idols are presented in an extremely negative light, something that an attentive reader would surely not have failed to notice. The excerpt concludes with a suggestion on how to refer to the great number of pagan gods: δῆμον and πολυαρχίαν θεῶν. The expression is very similar – indeed, it appears almost literally extracted – to what Theodore Metochites (1270‒1332) says in one of his orations for Saint Demetrius the Great Martyr (Or. 4, 12, 124 Kaltsogianni-Polemis) δῆμον θεῶν ἄτακτον καὶ πολυαρχίαν, καὶ θροῦν ἄλογον (“a confused crowd of gods and a polyarchy, and an senseless din”). If the source here is truly the writing of Theodore Metochites, it would be a citation of an author substantially contemporary with, or slightly preceding, the drafting of the two codices that have come down to us. It would follow that y should be dated later than the composition of the Byzantine scholar's oration, the precise date of which is unfortunately not known.
